Fig 3 Fig. 4 Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectrum(a) and Raman spectrum(b) of the samples. Fig 4 Fig. 5 XPS spectrum of Ti2p(a) and UV spectrum(b) of the samples. Fig 5 Fig. 6 XPS spectra of Mg1s of Mg-PSM(a),MgZn3-PSM(0.21)(c)and Zn2p of Zn-PSM(b), MgZn3-PSM(0.21)(d). Research Paper Catalytic Baeyer-Villiger oxidation of cyclohexanone over magnesium oxide-zinc oxide clusters supported on porous silica microspheres Guanhong Liang Writing – original draft Methodology Investigation Formal analysis a Yanchun Zheng Project administration Funding acquisition b Meidong Lang Writing – review & editing Project administration Funding acquisition a ⁎ a Shanghai Key Laboratory of Advanced Polymer Materials, Ministry of Education Key Laboratory of Ultrafine Materials, School of Materials Science and Engineering, East China University of Science and Technology, 130 Meilong Road, Shanghai 200237, China Shanghai Key Laboratory of Advanced Polymer Materials Ministry of Education Key Laboratory of Ultrafine Materials School of Materials Science and Engineering, East China University of Science and Technology 130 Meilong Road Shanghai 200237 China aShanghai Key Laboratory of Advanced Polymer Materials, Ministry of Education Key Laboratory of Ultrafine Materials, School of Materials Science and Engineering, East China University of Science and Technology, 130 Meilong Road, Shanghai 200237, China b Quzhou Juhua Polyamide Fibre LLC, 56 Juhua North Second Road, Quzhou 324000, Zhejiang Province, China Quzhou Juhua Polyamide Fibre LLC 56 Juhua North Second Road Quzhou Zhejiang Province 324000 China bQuzhou Juhua Polyamide Fibre LLC, 56 Juhua North Second Road, Quzhou 324000, Zhejiang Province, China ⁎ Corresponding author. ε-Caprolactone is an essential monomer for the synthesis of poly-caprolactone and is primarily produced via the Baeyer-Villiger oxidation of cyclohexanone. This study focuses on the preparation of MgZnx-PSMy catalysts by loading Mg and Zn onto porous silica microspheres for the hydrogen peroxide oxidation of cyclohexanone to ε-caprolactone. The metal oxides exist in the form of clusters. The catalysts were characterized using X-ray diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), nitrogen adsorption-desorption analysis, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), Raman spectroscopy, ultraviolet-visible spectroscopy (UV–Vis), and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) to confirm their successful synthesis. The effects of catalyst preparation method, metal molar ratios, metal-to-support mass ratios, catalyst dosage, reaction time, reaction temperature, and hydrogen peroxide concentration on catalytic performance were systematically investigated, along with the reusability of the catalyst. Under optimized conditions, with an Mg:Zn molar ratio of 3:1, a metal-to-porous silica microsphere mass ratio of 0.21, a catalyst loading of 5 % (relative to the mass of cyclohexanone), a reaction temperature of 80 °C, and a reaction time of 10 hours, the cyclohexanone conversion reached 91 %, with an ε-caprolactone selectivity of 93 % and a yield of 84 %. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Baeyer-Villiger oxidation Cyclohexanone Porous silica microspheres Magnesium oxide Zinc oxide Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Polymer materials have significantly enhanced the diversity and convenience of daily life. With societal advancements, their applications in both production and daily activities have expanded considerably. However, commonly used polymers such as polypropylene (PP), polyethylene (PE), polystyrene (PS), and polyvinyl chloride (PVC) are non-degradable. Once discarded, these materials persist in the environment, posing severe threats to ecosystems, including soils, oceans, lakes, and forests. To mitigate these environmental impacts, the development and adoption of degradable polymer materials are imperative. Among degradable polymers, polycaprolactone (PCL) stands out as a biodegradable polyester with exceptional mechanical properties and biocompatibility. Its versatility has made it widely applicable in areas such as food packaging, drug delivery [1], tissue engineering [2], and wound healing [3]. PCL is typically synthesized via the ring-opening polymerization of ε-caprolactone, which is primarily produced through the Baeyer–Villiger oxidation of cyclohexanone. In 1899, Adolf Baeyer and Victor Villiger first described the oxidation of menthone to its corresponding lactone using peroxysulfates and concentrated sulfuric acid [4]. Since then, the Baeyer–Villiger (BV) oxidation has become a cornerstone transformation in organic synthesis, with ε-caprolactone being a key monomer produced via the BV oxidation of cyclohexanone. Traditional BV oxidation employs organic peracids as oxidants, such as meta-chloroperoxybenzoic acid, peracetic acid, and trifluoroperacetic acid. These peracids exhibit strong oxidizing capabilities and achieve high conversion rates without requiring a catalyst. However, they are expensive, impact-sensitive, unstable, and associated with significant safety risks. Their production relies on hazardous concentrated hydrogen peroxide, which complicates transportation and storage. Moreover, peracid-based oxidations generate equivalent amounts of organic waste acids or acid salts, which are corrosive to equipment and may trigger secondary reactions, reducing selectivity. These drawbacks, along with environmental pollution concerns, underscore the need for safer, more stable, and environmentally friendly oxidants to replace traditional peracid systems. Alternative oxidants include molecular oxygen and hydrogen peroxide. Molecular oxygen has weak oxidation ability and cannot directly generate oxygen radicals to convert ketones into esters. Typically, an aldehyde is required as a sacrificial agent, such as benzaldehyde. In the O₂/aldehyde system, oxygen first reacts with the aldehyde to form a peracid, which then oxidizes the ketone to produce the corresponding ester. This mechanism is the basis of the Mukaiyama system developed by Yamada et al. [5]. Based on this approach, several catalysts have been reported for the Baeyer-Villiger oxidation of cyclohexanone. For instance, Lei Chen et al. developed a bifunctional Cu-SiO₂ catalyst with highly dispersed copper species in different oxidation states, achieving a cyclohexanone conversion exceeding 99 % and a selectivity toward ε-caprolactone greater than 99 % [6]. Katarzyna Pamin employed a two-step post-synthetic method to prepare Ti-Si-BEA zeolite. The process involved dealumination of siliceous zeolite using concentrated nitric acid, followed by titanium incorporation. The resulting Ti-Si-BEA zeolite was utilized for the liquid-phase Baeyer-Villiger oxidation of cyclohexanone in an oxygen-aldehyde system, achieving a maximum cyclohexanone conversion of 77.4 % and an optimal selectivity of 98.6 % toward ε-caprolactone [7]. Although catalysts based on this system have achieved remarkable performance, the oxygen/aldehyde system has several drawbacks. The organic acids produced as byproducts can cause environmental pollution, and aldehydes are high-cost raw materials. Additionally, the use of large quantities of oxygen poses safety risks, making this approach less suitable for green and safe production. Hydrogen peroxide is a green and environmentally friendly oxidant with a higher active oxygen content than peracids. Its oxidation process produces only water as a by-product, avoiding the challenges associated with peracid use. Furthermore, hydrogen peroxide is more cost-effective, widely available, and safer to transport and store, making it a superior alternative. However, at low concentrations, its oxidizing power is weak, necessitating the use of a catalyst. Certain enzymes, such as Baeyer–Villiger monooxygenases (BVMOs), are known to catalyze the oxidation of cyclohexanone with hydrogen peroxide. However, enzymes are prone to deactivation at high temperatures, are non-reusable, and are costly, making their application economically unfeasible. Non-enzymatic catalysts for this reaction are typically classified as homogeneous or heterogeneous based on their phase during the reaction. Homogeneous catalysts, such as ionic liquid-based Pt(II) systems [8], are challenging to recover and recycle. In contrast, heterogeneous catalysts are easily separated and reused, offering practical advantages. Corma et al. first reported in Nature the use of Sn-β zeolite as a heterogeneous catalyst for the Baeyer–Villiger oxidation of cyclohexanone with hydrogen peroxide, achieving a ε-caprolactone selectivity of 98 % and a cyclohexanone conversion rate of 52 % [9]. This study explained the activation of the carbonyl group by Sn, which has attracted considerable interest. This study highlighted the activation of the carbonyl group by Sn, sparking significant interest in Sn-based catalysts. Since then, various Sn-based catalysts [10–12] and other heterogeneous systems have been developed, employing metals such as Ti [13], Sn, Al [14], Pt [15], Co [16], Ag, and W [17]. These metals are often used in the form of oxides, complexes, or supported on materials such as zeolites, molecular sieves, or polymers. Despite these advancements, the catalytic activity of most systems in the Baeyer–Villiger oxidation of cyclohexanone remains relatively low. Natural minerals and oxides containing Mg have been reported to activate hydrogen peroxide in hydrogen peroxide/nitrile oxidation systems, forming hydroxy anions that subsequently generate peroxycrotonic acid for the Baeyer–Villiger oxidation of cyclohexanone [18]. However, these natural minerals and oxides exhibit low specific surface areas and poor Mg dispersion, which limits the exposure of active sites. Moreover, the primary role of Mg in these systems is to promote peroxide formation, which may further react with the lactone product, leading to low ε-caprolactone selectivity. Zn, as a Lewis acid, can coordinate with electron-donating groups such as carbonyls, thereby enhancing their reactivity [19]. This property makes Zn widely applicable in adsorption and catalysis, such as in the adsorption of phenol and the catalytic Diels-Alder cycloaddition-dehydration reaction between ethylene and 5-(methoxymethyl)furan-2-carboxylate [20], The hydrogenation of levulinic acid (LA) to γ-valerolactone (GVL) [19]. Therefore, the combined use of Mg and Zn is worth exploring. However, crystalline oxide structures exhibit poor dispersibility and low specific surface area, which hinder effective contact between the active components and the substrate, while also making the diffusion of reactants and products more challenging. Studies have reported that oxide clusters often exhibit superior catalytic performance compared to their crystalline counterparts [21]. Therefore, in this work, oxide clusters were immobilized on a high-surface-area porous support to enhance their catalytic activity. High-surface-area materials, such as zeolites and porous silica, possess excellent hydrothermal stability and have been extensively used as supports in catalytic applications. For instance, Fe-deposited ZSM-5 catalysts have been employed for the oxidation of cyclohexane to cyclohexanone [22], while TS-1 and Ti-modified SBA-15 have been studied for propylene epoxidation [23,24], indole hydrodenitrogenation [25], dry reforming of methane [26], and highly efficient oxidative desulfurization [27]. Additionally, porous silica-supported CeO₂-Pt catalysts have been applied in toluene combustion [28]. Other zeolites, such as Beta [29], AEI [30], and MCM-41 [31], are also frequently used as catalyst supports. Introducing heteroatoms such as Sn, Ti, and V into the silica framework can also generate additional acidic sites, thereby enhancing adsorption capacity. However, the preparation of these supports or catalysts often requires specialized procedures or equipment, making the synthesis process relatively complex. In summary, this study aims to develop a catalyst by loading magnesium oxide-zinc oxide onto a titanium-doped porous silica support prepared via a simple method, forming a cluster structure. By optimizing the Mg/Zn molar ratio, the metal-to-support ratio, and the reaction conditions, the catalyst is designed to efficiently promote the Baeyer-Villiger oxidation of cyclohexanone with hydrogen peroxide to produce ε-caprolactone. 2 Experimental 2.1material All chemicals were used as received without further purification. Tetraethyl orthosilicate (99 %), cyclohexanone (99 %), benzonitrile (99 %), Pluronic123 (98+%) were obtained from Adamas. Titanium tetraisopropanolate (97 %) was supplied by Alfa Aesar (China). Ethyl acetate, magnesium nitrate hexahydrate (AR), zinc nitrate hexahydrate (CP), and 30 % hydrogen peroxide were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd. Hydrochloric acid solution (36 %), acetonitrile (AR), and ammonia solution (25 %−28 %) were provided by General-Regent. 2.2 Preparation of magnesium-zinc composite oxides The Magnesium-Zinc composite oxides were prepared via a simple precipitation method. Magnesium nitrate hexahydrate and zinc nitrate hexahydrate, at a molar ratio of 3:1, were dissolved in deionized water. Ammonium hydroxide was used as a pH adjuster, added dropwise under stirring until the pH reached 10. The mixture was stirred continuously for 24 hours, after which the precipitate was separated and dried in an oven at 70 °C for 24 hours to remove moisture. The dried material was then calcined in a muffle furnace, with the temperature ramping at 10 °C per minute from 30 °C to 550 °C. The material was held at 550 °C for 5 hours to obtain the Magnesium-Zinc composite oxides, labeled as MgOZnO. Magnesium oxide and zinc oxide were prepared using the same method. 2.3 Synthesis of porous silica microspheres (PSM) Porous silica microspheres was synthesized using a conventional sol-gel method in an acidic medium, employing P123 as the template, tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) as the silicon source, and Titanium tetraisopropanolate (TIP) as the titanium source [32,33]. First, 10 g of P123 was dissolved in 232 mL of hydrochloric acid solution (pH < 1) under stirring at 35 °C for 2 hours until completely dissolved. A mixture of 20 mL TEOS and 2.6 mL TIP was added dropwise under vigorous stirring using a constant-pressure dropping funnel. After stirring for 30 min, the solution was allowed to react statically at 35 °C for 24 hours, followed by crystallization at 80 °C for another 24 hours. The solid product was separated, dried at 70 °C for 24 hours to remove moisture, and then calcined in a muffle furnace. The temperature was increased at a rate of 10 °C per minute from 30 °C to 550 °C and maintained at 550 °C for 5 hours to remove the template, yielding porous silica microspheres. The product obtained without the addition of TIP is designated as PSM(Si). 2.4 Synthesis of MgZn-PSM 2.4.1 Precipitation method To prepare the catalyst, 1 g of PSM was dispersed in 25 mL of deionized water, followed by the addition of calculated amounts of magnesium nitrate hexahydrate and zinc nitrate hexahydrate. The pH of the solution was adjusted to 10 using ammonium hydroxide, and the mixture was stirred at room temperature for 24 hours. The resulting solid was separated by centrifugation, washed with deionized water until the pH of the wash reached 7, and dried overnight at 70 °C to remove moisture. Finally, the material was calcined at 550 °C for 5 hours. The prepared catalyst was designated as MgZnx-PSM(y), where x represents the molar ratio of Mg/Zn, and y indicates the mass ratio of Mg and Zn to PSM in the precursor. Catalysts containing only Mg or Zn were also prepared using the same method and were denoted as Mg-PSM and Zn-PSM, respectively. 2.4.2 Wet impregnation method 1 g of PSM was impregnated in 2 mL of an ethanol solution containing a calculated amount of magnesium nitrate hexahydrate and zinc nitrate hexahydrate. The mixture was subjected to ultrasonic treatment until the ethanol was completely evaporated. The resulting impregnated solid was thoroughly dried and subsequently calcined at 550 °C for 5 h to obtain the catalyst, denoted as MgZnx-PSMy(WI), where x represents the molar ratio of Mg/Zn, y denotes the mass ratio of Mg and Zn precursors to PSM, and WI indicates that the catalyst was prepared by the wet impregnation method. 2.4.3 Solid-State impregnation method 1 g of PSM was thoroughly ground with a calculated amount of magnesium nitrate hexahydrate and zinc nitrate hexahydrate in an agate mortar. The mixture was then calcined at 550 °C for 5 h to obtain the catalyst, denoted as MgZnx-PSMy(SSI), where x represents the molar ratio of Mg/Zn, y denotes the mass ratio of Mg and Zn precursors to PSM, and SSI indicates that the catalyst was prepared by the solid-state impregnation method. 2.5 Catalyst characterization 2.5.1 SEM The surface morphology of the catalysts was observed using a Hitachi S4800 cold field-emission scanning electron microscope. The acceleration voltage was set to 15 kV. Samples were fixed on circular sample holders with conductive carbon tape and gold-coated before imaging. 2.5.2 XRD The crystalline structure of the catalysts was analyzed using a Bruker D8 Advance ECO X-ray diffractometer with CuKα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) under conditions of 1 kW, 40 kV, and 25 mA. Wide-angle XRD patterns were recorded in the 2θ range of 10°–80° at a scanning rate of 1°/min. 2.5.3 Nitrogen adsorption-desorption Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms were recorded at −196 °C (liquid nitrogen temperature) using a Quadrasorb SI surface area and pore size analyzer. Samples were degassed under vacuum at 200 °C for 3 hours prior to measurement. Specific surface areas were calculated using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method over a relative pressure range of 0.01–1. Pore volume and pore size were determined by the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. 2.5.4 FT-IR Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra of the catalysts were recorded using a Nicolet iS50 spectrometer. Spectra were scanned 32 times in the range of 4000–400 cm⁻¹ with a resolution of 4 cm⁻¹. KBr was used as the background material. Prior to testing, samples were dried to remove moisture and then mixed with KBr and pressed into pellets. The in situ FT-IR spectra were recorded using a Nicolet iS50 FT-IR spectrometer equipped with an attenuated total reflectance (ATR) accessory. During measurements, the sample was placed on a diamond crystal sample stage, and spectra were collected at 10-minute intervals. 2.5.5 UV–Vis Ultraviolet-visible (UV–Vis) absorption spectra were recorded using a Shimadzu UV-2450/2550 spectrophotometer. Scanning was conducted in the range of 200–600 nm, using barium sulfate as the reference material. Samples were evenly spread on the surface of barium sulfate for measurement. 2.5.6 Raman spectroscopy Raman spectra of the catalysts were obtained using a DXR3xi confocal micro-Raman spectrometer equipped with a 532 nm laser. The spectral range was 50–3500 cm⁻¹. 2.5.7 XPS The surface chemical composition and electronic states of the catalysts were analyzed using a Thermo Scientific K-Alpha X-ray photoelectron spectrometer. The instrument employed a monochromatic Al Kα X-ray source (E = 1486.68 eV). The step size was 0.5 eV, with a voltage of 1.2 kV and a current of 6 mA. The binding energy was calibrated using the adventitious C1s peak at 284.80 eV. 2.6 Catalytic activity testing The Baeyer-Villiger oxidation of cyclohexanone was conducted in a 10 mL flask equipped with a coiled condenser and a magnetic stirrer. A mixture of 140 μL (1.4 mmol) cyclohexanone, 0.81 mL (8 mmol) benzonitrile, and 1.14 mL (10 mmol) 30 % aqueous hydrogen peroxide was dissolved in 2.84 mL of acetonitrile. Subsequently, 16.5 mg of sodium bicarbonate and 4 mg of catalyst were added, and the reaction was carried out at 80 °C for 10 hours. After the reaction, the catalyst was removed by centrifugation, and the reaction solutions before and after the reaction were analyzed using a Shimadzu GC-2010 gas chromatograph equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) to determine the concentrations of the target compounds. GC–MS was also employed for further identification and analysis of the target compounds. 2.7 Evaluation of catalytic performance The conversion of cyclohexanone, the yield of ε-caprolactone, and the selectivity toward ε-caprolactone were determined based on the following equations. Cyclohexanone Conversion(XCYC): C c y c 0 − C c y c 1 C c y c 0 % Yield of ε-Caprolactone(Yε-CL): C ε − c l C c y c 0 % Selectivity of ε-Caprolactone(Sε-CL): Y i e l d o f ε − C a p r o l a c t o n e C y c l o h e x a n o n e C o n v e r s i o n % C c y c 0 represents the initial concentration of cyclohexanone before the reaction, C c y c 1 represents the concentration of cyclohexanone after the reaction, and C ε − c l represents the concentration of ε-caprolactone after the reaction 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization The surface morphology of the catalysts was analyzed via scanning electron microscopy (SEM). Fig. 1 illustrates the SEM images of PSM and those modified with Mg and Zn. Fig. 1a reveals that the PSM support exhibits a spherical morphology with diameters ranging from 3 to 6 μm. Similar spherical structures have been previously reported [33], indicating that silica microspheres were successfully synthesized through a simple method. Notably, slight agglomer-ation of microspheres was observed, likely due to the rapid addition of the TEOS/TIP precursor mixture during synthesis. This issue could potentially be alleviated by introducing an emulsifying agent or precisely controlling the addition rate of the precursor solution. Before the incorporation of Mg and Zn, the microspheres displayed smooth and well-defined surfaces. After the deposition of Mg and Zn through a precipitation method, irregular block-like particles were observed on the surface. This morphological transformation is attributed to the localized deposition of Mg and Zn oxides on the porous silica microspheres framework, indicating successful loading of Mg and Zn onto the porous silica microspheres. The SEM images of the catalysts prepared by wet impregnation and solid-state impregnation, as well as those of the metal oxides, are shown in Figure S1. The crystallographic information of the catalysts was determined using wide-angle X-ray diffraction. Fig. 2 presents the wide-angle X-ray diffraction patterns of different samples. The XRD pattern of MgOZnO is shown in Fig. 2a, where characteristic diffraction lines of ZnO and MgO are observed at 32.0°, 34.7°, 36.5°, 47.8°, 56.8°, 63.1°, 68.1°, and 69.3°, corresponding to the crystal planes (100), (002), (101), (102), (110), (103), and (112) of ZnO [34], respectively. The diffraction lines at 43.1°, 62.4°, and 77.2° correspond to the (200), (220), and (222) crystal planes of MgO [35]. In the MgOZnO composite oxide, ZnO exhibits a higher degree of crystallinity. For the different types of supported catalysts (Fig. 2b), a broad and weak diffraction line appears at 22.3°, corresponding to amorphous silica [36], while no significant characteristic diffraction lines of MgO or ZnO are observed. This suggests that Mg and Zn are well-dispersed on the surface of the support, or exist in small clusters, without large-scale crystalline aggregation. Magnesium oxide-zinc oxide clusters were successfully formed on the surface of the porous silica support. As shown in the XRD patterns of the catalysts prepared by wet impregnation and solid-state impregnation (Figure S2a), distinct diffraction peaks corresponding to ZnO and MgO are observed, indicating the formation of large crystalline aggregates. This suggests that the metal oxides in the physically impregnated catalysts exhibit lower dispersion compared to those prepared by the precipitation method. To determine the porous characteristics of the catalysts, the samples were degassed in N₂ atmosphere at 200 °C for 3 hours. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were recorded in the relative pressure range of 0.1–1 at −196 °C, as shown in Fig. 3 a. Both PSM and MgZn3-PSM(0.21) exhibited type IV isotherms, indicative of mesoporous structures according to IUPAC classification. In the low-pressure region (0–0.4 relative pressure), PSM demonstrated microporous adsorption characteristics, suggesting the presence of micropores in the support. In the relative pressure range of 0.4–0.8, the H Ⅰ-type hysteresis loop was observed, indicating uniform pore size distribution. The pore size distribution of the aforementioned samples is shown in Fig. 3b PSM had a mesopore diameter centered around 3.4 nm, while MgZn3-PSM(0.21) had its pore size predominantly centered around 3.8 nm. The specific surface area, average pore diameter, and pore volume of the samples are summarized in Table 1 . After loading Mg and Zn, the specific surface area of the sample decreased from 659.5 m²/g to 260.5 m²/g, and the average pore volume reduced from 0.36 cm³/g to 0.27 cm³/g. These changes can be attributed to the loading of Mg and Zn. The average pore diameter increased from 3.2 nm to 4.4 nm, which may be attributed to the blockage or destruction of micropores during the loading process. Upon the incorporation of Mg and Zn, the average pore diameter increased from 3.2 nm to 4.4 nm. This enlargement is attributed to the partial blockage or collapse of micropores during the metal oxide loading process. Specifically, after metal oxide deposition, the micropore volume of PSM decreased from 0.05 cm³/g to 0.03 cm³/g, and the corresponding micropore surface area dropped from 103.4 m²/g to 57.5 m²/g. This is likely due to the formation of metal oxide clusters within the micropores during the precipitation process, leading to pore obstruction and structural degradation. As a result, the contribution of micropores to the overall pore structure diminished, thereby increasing the average pore size. This phenomenon is also evident in the nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms, where the pristine PSM exhibits microporous characteristics in the low relative pressure range (P/P₀ = 0–0.4), which are notably weakened in the Mg and Zn loaded samples. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) and Raman spectroscopy were employed to analyze the chemical structure of the catalysts. The spectra are shown in Fig. 4 a. In the FT-IR spectrum of PSM(Si), absorption bands at 460 cm⁻¹, 830 cm⁻¹, and 1082 cm⁻¹ correspond to the bending vibration, symmetric stretching vibration, and asymmetric stretching vibration of the Si-O-Si bond, respectively [36]. An additional band at 960 cm⁻¹ is observed, attributed to the stretching vibration of Si-OH. In the PSM spectrum, the intensity of the band at 960 cm⁻¹ is reduced, indicating partial replacement of hydroxyl groups by Ti, confirming the incorporation of Ti into the framework. After the loading of Mg and Zn, the intensity of the band at 960 cm⁻¹ further decreases, and no distinct band is observed, suggesting the binding of Mg and Zn with the hydroxyl groups to form metal oxides. This finding is also supported by XPS analysis. Compared to FT-IR, Raman spectroscopy is less affected by water interference and offers higher resolution for weak dipole bonds or symmetric bonds. Therefore, Raman spectroscopy was further employed to study the chemical structure of the catalysts. Fig. 4b shows the Raman spectra of PSM, MgZn3-PSM(0.21), Mg-PSM, and Zn-PSM. In the Raman spectrum of PSM, four Raman bands were observed at 488 cm⁻¹, 816 cm⁻¹, 966 cm⁻¹, and 1105 cm⁻¹, corresponding to the asymmetric stretching vibration of Si-O-Si, the symmetric stretching vibration of Si-O-Si, the Raman band related to Si-OH defects in the Si-O-Si framework, and the asymmetric stretching vibration of Si-O-Ti, respectively [37]. These results confirm the successful incorporation of Ti. After the precipitation method for loading Mg and Zn, the intensity of the Raman band at 966 cm⁻¹, associated with Si-OH, significantly decreases, indicating a reduction in Si-OH content, which can be attributed to the binding of Mg and Zn with hydroxyl. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was used to characterize the catalyst and determine the chemical states of the surface elements. Charge correction was performed using the external C1s reference at 284.80 eV. Table 2 presents the chemical composition information of the catalysts. Fig. 5 a shows the Ti2p XPS spectrum of PSM, where two strong signals are observed at 460.19 eV and 465.68 eV, corresponding to Ti2p3/2 and Ti2p1/2, respectively. The binding energies are significantly higher than those of typical TiO2 compounds. Literature reports suggest that when Ti or other metals are incorporated into the framework of molecular sieves, they often exhibit higher binding energies than typical metal oxides [7]. This result indicates the successful incorporation of Ti into the PSM framework. This is further supported by the UV spectrum (Fig. 5b), where all samples show an absorption band centered at 210 nm. This absorption is directly related to the pπ-dπ electronic transition between Ti and O in isolated Ti sites within the framework, confirming the successful incorporation of Ti into the molecular sieve structure. No significant absorption band is observed around 300 nm, indicating the absence of extraframework Ti species such as TiO2 [37]. After loading Mg and Zn metal oxides, no significant shift in the absorption band centered at 210 nm was observed; however, the intensity decreased. This is attributed to the formation of Mg, Zn oxide clusters, which reduced the concentration of framework Ti atoms in the system. The XPS spectra of Mg1s and Zn2p for Mg-PSM(Fig. 6 a), Zn-PSM(Fig. 6b), and MgZn3-PSM(0.21) (Fig. 6c,d)are shown in Fig. 6. In the Zn2p spectrum of MgZn3-PSM(0.21), two signal peaks are observed at 1022.46 eV and 1045.40 eV (Fig. 6d), corresponding to the Zn2p3/2 and Zn2p1/2 binding energies of divalent ZnO [38]. These peaks result from spin-orbit splitting, confirming that Zn is present on the surface of the support in the form of divalent zinc oxide. For the Zn-PSM catalyst, the binding energies are 1022.42 eV and 1045.43 eV, indicating that the composite with MgO causes a slight shift in binding energy. A similar difference in binding energy is also observed in the Mg1s spectrum. In MgZn3-PSM(0.21), a signal peak at 1304.51 eV corresponds to the Mg1s binding energy of divalent magnesium oxide, confirming the successful incorporation of Mg in the form of an oxide on the surface. The Mg1s binding energy for Mg-PSM is 1304.30 eV, which shows a slightly higher binding energy after the combination with Zn. These results demonstrate the successful incorporation of Mg and Zn onto the support surface. 3.2 Catalytic testing The Baeyer-Villiger oxidation of cyclohexanone was conducted using 30 % hydrogen peroxide as the oxidant and acetonitrile as the solvent. Acetonitrile was chosen because it can dissolve cyclohexanone, benzyl cyanide, and other organic compounds while being miscible with water. This enables the reaction mixture to remain homogeneous, enhancing the contact between hydrogen peroxide and cyclohexanone. Upon oxidation, cyclohexanone is converted to ε-caprolactone. A blank experiment without the addition of a catalyst was conducted prior to the catalytic activity tests, and no formation of ε-caprolactone was observed. The catalytic performance of unsupported metal oxides was evaluated as a control, and the catalytic activities of catalysts prepared by different methods were also investigated. The results are summarized in Table 3 . When using un-supported metal oxides as catalysts, the yield of ε-caprolactone did not exceed 51 %. Upon supporting the metal oxides on the PSM material, all catalysts exhibited improved catalytic performance regardless of the preparation method. Among them, the catalyst MgZn3-PSM(0.21), prepared via the precipitation method, showed the best performance, achieving a ε-caprolactone yield of 75 % and a corresponding cyclohexanone conversion of 81 %. This is attributed to the formation of crystalline oxide aggregates in the catalysts prepared via wet impregnation and solid-state impregnation methods (Figure S1a), indicating poor dispersion of the metal oxides. In contrast, the presence of non-crystalline metal oxide clusters is crucial for achieving high catalytic activity. The catalytic performance of Mg-PSM, Zn-PSM, and various Mg:Zn ratios (ranging from 4:1 to 1:2) was investigated. Table 4 summarizes the influence of the metal ratio on catalytic activity. It is evident from the table that, when using monometallic catalysts, the Mg-loaded catalyst exhibited a higher cyclohexanone conversion rate of 79.63 %, but the selectivity for ε-caprolactone was only 81.09 %. In contrast, Zn-PSM showed lower conversion (69 %) but higher selectivity (96 %). This difference is attributed to the distinct roles played by Mg and Zn in the reaction. Mg primarily promotes the formation of peroxycarbamates, a stronger oxidizing species, through its interaction with hydrogen peroxide and benzyl cyanide, whereas Zn coordinates with the carbonyl group of cyclohexanone, facilitating its oxidation. When Mg and Zn are combined, the synergistic effect of the two metals resulted in the highest yield of the target product, ε-caprolactone, at 75 %, achieved at a Mg:Zn ratio of 3:1. The catalytic performance of crystalline magnesium-zinc composite oxides was also evaluated, yielding only 51 % ε-caprolactone. After determining the optimal Mg:Zn ratio, the effects of the metal-to-support mass ratio, catalyst amount, reaction time, and reaction temperature on conversion rate and product yield were further investigated. Additionally, the catalyst's recyclability was tested, which is crucial for its industrial application. Table 5 shows that as the metal-to-PSM mass ratio decreases, both the conversion rate of cyclohexanone and the yield of ε-caprolactone decrease, which is associated with a reduction in the number of active sites. However, the highest selectivity for ε-caprolactone, reaching 97 %, was observed at a ratio of 0.14 and 0.21. Based on the above results, MgZn3-PSM(0.21) was selected as the catalyst for investigating the reaction conditions. Reducing the catalyst amount is of significant importance in minimizing production costs. However, both insufficient and excessive catalyst amounts can adversely affect the reaction. Consequently, the impact of catalyst dosage on reaction performance was investigated, as illustrated in Fig. 7 . The mass percentage of catalyst relative to cyclohexanone was varied from 1 % to 10 %. As the catalyst amount increased, the cyclohexanone conversion rate exhibited an initial increase followed by a decrease, with the highest conversion rate of 91 % observed at a catalyst loading of 5 %. Insufficient catalyst dosage resulted in a limited number of active sites, leading to a decrease in the overall reaction rate and conversion. Conversely, an excessive catalyst amount also negatively affected the reaction. The selectivity toward ε-caprolactone remained approximately 90 % under varying catalyst dosages. The highest ε-caprolactone selectivity, 93 %, was achieved at a catalyst dosage of 5 %, corresponding to an ε-caprolactone yield of 84 %. Fig. 8 shows the variation of conversion rate, selectivity, and yield of ε-caprolactone over reaction time. Within the first two hours, the conversion rate of cyclohexanone reached 48 %, close to 50 %, while the selectivity towards ε-caprolactone reached 100 %. After 4 hours, the conversion rate of cyclohexanone increased by 12 %, reaching 60 %, and the yield of ε-caprolactone increased by 11 %, reaching 59 %. The selectivity towards ε-caprolactone decreased by 1 %. After 6 hours, the conversion rate of cyclohexanone reached 70 %, with a selectivity of 98 % and a yield of 68 %. Beyond 4 hours, the conversion rate of cyclohexanone increased by only 11 %, reaching 81 %, while the selectivity towards ε-caprolactone dropped to 92 %, and the yield increased by 7 %, reaching 75 %. The conversion rate of cyclohexanone reached 48 % in the first two hours and then gradually increased to 81 % over the next 8 hours. Overall, the conversion rate of cyclohexanone increased with reaction time, but the reaction rate slowed down as the reaction progressed. This is attributed to the decreasing concentration of reactants, such as cyclohexanone and hydrogen peroxide, over time. The selectivity towards ε-caprolactone also decreased with extended reaction time, likely due to increased side reactions, resulting in the further oxidation of ε-caprolactone into other products. The yield of ε-caprolactone gradually increased with reaction time. The influence of reaction temperature on catalytic performance is presented in Table 6 . As expected, the conversion of cyclohexanone increases with rising temperature, reaching a maximum conversion of 81 % near the boiling point of the solvent acetonitrile at 80 °C. The selectivity toward ε-caprolactone generally improves with increasing temperature, with the highest selectivity of 92 % observed at 80 °C. Therefore, 80 °C is identified as the optimal reaction temperature. The effect of varying the oxidizing agent was also investigated. Table 7 presents the results of the reaction with different multiplicities of hydrogen peroxide. It is evident that increasing the amount of hydrogen peroxide has a substantial impact on enhancing the conversion of cyclohexanone, which aligns with the anticipated outcomes. Furthermore, augmenting the quantity of hydrogen peroxide does not diminish the selectivity of the product towards ε-caprolactone. However, excessive utilization of the oxidizing agent may lead to unfavorable outcomes. The use of an excess of hydrogen peroxide will result in increased costs and a reduction in safety. Therefore, the molar ratio of hydrogen peroxide to cyclohexanone was limited to 7.5. Under these conditions, the conversion of cyclohexanone reached 81 %, the selectivity of the product to ε-caprolactone reached 92 %, and the yield of ε-caprolactone was 75 %. A major advantage of heterogeneous catalysts over homogeneous catalysts and enzyme catalysis is their recyclability. Therefore, the reutilization performance of the catalyst was investigated, and the results are shown in Fig. 9 . The catalyst demonstrated good stability and catalytic activity during the first three cycles, maintaining a conversion rate above 81 % and selectivity above 89 %. However, after the fourth use, the conversion rate decreased significantly. To understand the cause of the catalyst deactivation, XPS characterization was conducted on the catalyst after five cycles of use. XPS analysis of the catalyst after five reaction cycles is shown in Fig. 10 . In the C 1 s spectrum(Fig. 10a), aside from the external C 1 s peak used for calibration, three additional peaks were observed at 286.61 eV, 288.51 eV, and 292.52 eV, which were absent prior to use. These peaks can be attributed to C–O single bonds, C = O groups in ketones, and C = O bonds in esters within ε-caprolactone, respectively. In the O 1s(Fig. 10b) spectrum, the peak at 531.10 eV corresponds to the binding energy of oxygen in MgO and ZnO, the peak at 531.89 eV is assigned to oxygen in organic C–O bonds, and the peak at 532.96 eV corresponds to oxygen in Si–O bonds.These results suggest that organic compounds, such as unreacted cyclohexanone or ring-opened ε-caprolactone, were adsorbed onto the catalyst surface during the reaction, likely at the active sites, contributing to catalyst deactivation. After calcination of the spent catalyst, its activity partially recovered, achieving a ε-caprolactone yield of 71 %. In addition, a significant decrease in the intensity of Mg and Zn XPS peaks was observed compared to the fresh catalyst, indicating possible leaching of the active metal species. This suggests that the acidic nature of hydrogen peroxide may cause partial dissolution or degradation of Mg and Zn species, further contributing to the loss of catalytic performance. 3.3 Reaction mechanism Based on relevant literature and our experimental characterization results [18], we propose the reaction pathway illustrated in Fig. 11 . Under the activation of catalytic sites, hydrogen peroxide initially oxidizes benzonitrile to generate a peroxycarboximidic acid intermediate. In the subsequent step, this intermediate undergoes a nucleophilic attack on the carbonyl group of cyclohexanone, which is activated by the Lewis acid sites of the catalyst, leading to the formation of a Criegee intermediate. This intermediate then undergoes a rearrangement to yield the target product, ε-caprolactone, along with benzamide as a by-product. The formation of benzamide, as confirmed by GC–MS analysis of the reaction solution (Fig. 12 ), supports the proposed reaction mechanism. In situ ATR-FTIR spectra of benzonitrile (Fig. 13 a) and cyclohexanone (Fig. 13b) adsorbed on MgZn3-PSM(0.21) were recorded. A red shift in the characteristic absorption bands corresponding to the nitrile group of benzonitrile and the carbonyl group of cyclohexanone was observed, indicating a shift to lower wavenumbers. This phenomenon can be attributed to the interaction between the Lewis acid sites on the catalyst and the electron-rich nitrile group and carbonyl group, suggesting that the catalyst effectively activates both benzonitrile and cyclohexanone. The complete in situ IR spectra are provided in Figure S3. 4 Conclusion A Ti-doped porous silica support (PSM) was successfully synthesized, and Mg and Zn were deposited onto the PSM support via a precipitation method to form oxide clusters, thereby preparing a series of MgZn-PSM catalysts with varying metal molar ratios and loading amounts. The physicochemical properties of the catalysts were systematically characterized using X-ray diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), nitrogen adsorption-desorption analysis, Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), Raman spectroscopy, ultraviolet-visible spectroscopy (UV–vis), and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The catalytic performance of these materials was evaluated in the Baeyer-Villiger oxidation of cyclohexanone to ε-caprolactone using hydrogen peroxide as the oxidant. The influence of key parameters, including the catalyst preparation method, Mg/Zn molar ratio, metal loading, catalyst dosage, reaction temperature, and reaction time, on catalytic efficiency was investigated, and optimal reaction conditions were determined. The results indicate that both Mg and Zn play essential roles in the catalytic process, while catalysts containing only Mg or Zn fail to achieve both high conversion and selectivity. Under the synergistic effect of Mg and Zn, the optimized catalyst exhibited a cyclohexanone conversion of 91 %, an ε-caprolactone selectivity of 93 %, and an ε-caprolactone yield of 84 %. Additionally, the catalyst demonstrated excellent recyclability, maintaining high catalytic activity over the first three cycles and retaining significant stability in subsequent cycles. This study provides a promising catalytic system for the Baeyer-Villiger oxidation of cyclohexanone in a hydrogen peroxide-based system and offers valuable insights into catalyst design, preparation parameters, and reaction optimization for the efficient synthesis of ε-caprolactone. coredata.dc:description: ε-Caprolactone is an essential monomer for the synthesis of poly-caprolactone and is primarily produced via the Baeyer-Villiger oxidation of cyclohexanone. This study focuses on the preparation of MgZnx-PSMy catalysts by loading Mg and Zn onto porous silica microspheres for the hydrogen peroxide oxidation of cyclohexanone to ε-caprolactone. The metal oxides exist in the form of clusters. The catalysts were characterized using X-ray diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), nitrogen adsorption-desorption analysis, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), Raman spectroscopy, ultraviolet-visible spectroscopy (UV–Vis), and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) to confirm their successful synthesis. The effects of catalyst preparation method, metal molar ratios, metal-to-support mass ratios, catalyst dosage, reaction time, reaction temperature, and hydrogen peroxide concentration on catalytic performance were systematically investigated, along with the reusability of the catalyst. Under optimized conditions, with an Mg:Zn molar ratio of 3:1, a metal-to-porous silica microsphere mass ratio of 0.21, a catalyst loading of 5 % (relative to the mass of cyclohexanone), a reaction temperature of 80 °C, and a reaction time of 10 hours, the cyclohexanone conversion reached 91 %, with an ε-caprolactone selectivity of 93 % and a yield of 84 %.
